awd_titl_txt: Synthesis of d- and p-Block Element Molecules, Reagents, and Precursors
awd_abstract_narration:
Funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Christopher Cummins of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology leads a project aimed at producing new kinds of chemical compounds containing phosphorus.  Phosphorus is a required component of fertilizers, semiconductors, and catalysts.  Cummins is inventing new compounds of phosphorus that are sufficiently stable to be handled in the laboratory but reactive enough that they can serve as ingredients to useful products. The group is developing "spring-loaded" compounds that deliver very reactive molecules that contain phosphorus.  These new entities are combined with organic compounds to give new and often unexpected products.  Some of the new reactive phosphorus compounds are short-lived, being stable only for seconds at low temperatures.  It is speculated that these short-lived compounds occur in the outer space, where even highly reactive molecules are stable.  Thus Professor Cummins aims to correlate data from his laboratory with astronomical measurements. Overall, the research is highly collaborative, involving scientists in academia, national laboratories, and industry. The project provides hands-on training for graduate and undergraduate students who are exposed to multiple tools and ways of thinking about chemistry.  Furthermore, the research connects and cross fertilizes multiple areas, including radioastronomy, microelectronics, and chemistry.  In addition to traditional publishing venues, the Cummins group produces videos of synthetic procedures. These videos are posted on YouTube to facilitate adoption of protocols by other researchers and to provide the public with a window into the practice of synthetic chemistry. In this way, this research reaches well beyond the laboratory, inspiring young aspiring scientists to develop technical skills.

Funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Christopher Cummins of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology leads a project aimed at producing new kinds of organophosphorus compounds.  This project focuses on the development of molecular precursors resulting from the expulsion of a neutral leaving group, such as anthracene, upon irradiation or thermal activation. This strategies provide access to reactive intermediates such as phosphinidenes or phosphacyclobutadienes. The reactive intermediate can be transferred to a suitable acceptor molecule for reactions carried out in solution, or released into the gas phase to enable studies by molecular beam mass spectrometry, microwave spectroscopy, and laser-induced fluorescence. Isolated reaction products are characterized by multinuclear NMR spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography. The experimental work is complemented by quantum chemical calculations designed to reveal details of bonding and to elucidate reaction mechanisms by potential energy surface explorations. The work is broadly impactful because of the centrality of phosphorus in everyday life, e.g. in fertilizers, microelectronics, and catalysis.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The chemistry of reactive intermediates can be harnessed to drive the development of new synthetic methods in organic and inorganic chemistry. Fleeting reactive intermediates are of interest for their intrinsic properties, which we investigate using theoretical methods combined with modern experimental techniques. It is possible to generate reactive intermediates as free species, either in the gas phase or in liquid solutions, and to trap them with reaction partners in processes leading to new chemical bonds. Synthetic molecular precursors can be designed and synthesized to be able to release a reactive intermediate upon the action of a stimulus, such as thermal activation, or irradiation with light. It is also possible, in a complementary manner to use synthetic molecular precursors as group transfer reagents to form new chemical bonds.

The phosphinidene transfer strategy has proven to be a valuable methodology in synthetic chemistry. We used phosphinidene transfer to an unsaturated ketone in our synthesis of a novel type of heterocycle, a phosphafuran. In exploring the reaction chemistry of the phosphafuran, we discovered that it has the ability to reversibly bind to unactivated alkenes including ethylene. The phosphinidene transfer approach was also applied to the synthesis of ruthenium phosphinidene complexes. The latter formed the basis of a study of what could be learned using solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy about the nature of the metal-ligand multiple bonds in such systems. We carried out a collaborative theoretical investigation of the nature of hydrogen-hydrogen bonds in a synthetic construct containing a high level of branching in the hydrocarbon component of its molecular structure. We have long sought, and have now successfully synthesized, a molecular precursor to the highly reactive phosphorus mononitride diatomic molecule, a molecule of interest to astrochemists for its known presence in space. The molecular precursor is an explosive compound capable upon heating of evolving phosphorus mononitride into the gas phase. We also demonstrated its capability to transfer phosphorus mononitride to suitable acceptors in the liquid phase, permitting the first synthesis of an iron complex with intact phosphorus mononitride as a coordinated ligand. Oxidation of the phosphorus mononitride molecular precursor provided a synthon for a heavy analog of nitrous oxide. Using the latter synthon, it was possible to capture phosphorus mononitride oxide in a chemically stabilized form. The release of strain energy can be used as a driving force for chemical reactions. We illustrated this principle in a nickel-catalyzed transfer of a phosphinidene to unactivated alkenes, including ethylene. This new catalytic reaction for making phosphorus-containing three-membered rings is analogous to more established methods for forming carbon-, nitrogen-, or oxgen-containing three-membered ring structures. We also investigated a phosphorus-containing analog of a classic reactive intermediate from organic chemistry, cyclobutadiene. Like cyclobutadiene, phospha-cyclobutadiene has a rich chemistry by which it undergoes dimerization, binds to transition metals, or engages unsaturated organic molecules in cycloaddition reactions. We used titanium chemistry developed in our lab to stabilize an unusual type of singlet carbene, which could then be use as the basic component of a frustrated Lewis pair capable of splitting molecular hydrogen. On their own, phosphaazides are not stable compounds and have never been isolated. We synthesized a molecular precursor to a phosphaazide and used it to probe the reactivity patterns of this essentially unknown chemical functional group. We developed the hypothesis that replacement of carbon by phosphorus in strained organic molecules alleviates that strain. The hypothesis was tested with the synthesis of triphosphatetrahedrane, a simple new molecule composed entirely of phosphorus, carbon, and hydrogen. Triphosphatetrahedrane completed a series of mixed carbon-phosphorus tetrahedra, and it is a molecule that potentially exists in interstellar space. With our astrochemistry collaborator, we are collecting experimental data on this molecule to enable its possible detection in space. We developed a new version of our iron-catalyzed reaction for phosphinidene transfer to unactivated alkenes. The development of iron-catalyzed reactions is important because iron is earth-abundant and inexpensive, and also because it opens up new chemical pathways for catalysis that differ from those characteristic of the expensive noble metals.

These studies formed the basis, in part, for the Ph.D. thesis research of three graduate students. One of these students has gone on to postdoctoral studies at UCLA, while one has completed his postdoctoral studies and now has an Assistant Professor position. Also participating was a Humboldt-funded postdoctoral scholar, now back in Germany with an independent faculty position, and a visiting graduate student from Germany. The studies laid the groundwork for our current and future research investigations, as well as for several ongoing collaborations. Together with our published fundamental scientific findings, the education of undergraduate and graduate students, and the advanced training of postdoctoral scientists and visiting scholars, make up the most significant outcomes from the award. The new reagents and synthetic methods we have developed are now available for use and study by other researchers.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2023
Modified by: Christopher C Cummins
